reviewText:
Midkine (MDK) also known as neurite growth-promoting factor 2 (NEGF2) is a protein that in humans is encoded by the MDK gene.

Midkine is a basic heparin-binding growth factor of low molecular weight, and forms a family with pleiotrophin (NEGF1, 46% homologous with MDK). It is a nonglycosylated protein, composed of two domains held by disulfide bridges. It is a developmentally important retinoic acid-responsive gene product strongly induced during mid-gestation, hence the name midkine . Restricted mainly to certain tissues in the normal adult, it is strongly induced during oncogenesis, inflammation and tissue repair.

MDK is pleiotropic, capable of exerting activities such as cell proliferation, cell migration, angiogenesis and fibrinolysis. A molecular complex containing receptor-type tyrosine phosphatase zeta (PTPζ), low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein (LRP1), anaplastic leukemia kinase (ALK) and syndecans is considered to be its receptor.

This is the sequel to that.

reviewText:
MDK2 is one of the best games ever made. Now let's get to the details :P

This game is a TPP puzzle platformer. You take control (simultaneously) over 3 characters: Kurt, mechanical dog Max and genius doctor Hawkins. Each character has completely different playstyle and emphasis on certain mechanics (Kurt - sniper rifle, parachute, lots of platforming, Max - less platforming, but can handle 4 firearms (!), Doctor - solving puzzles using some of his weird, science gear (atomic toaster for example :P). The goal is the usual one - save the earth against aliens :P

What else? Great humour, likable characters, goofy enemies, massive and colorful locations, kick ♥♥♥ music, epic boss battles, really funny cutscenes, unforgettable missions, cartoonish graphics that didn't age at all... But the best thing about MDK2 is that it feels really light and fun :)

So if you haven't played this game yet, I would strongly recommend picking it up. Great stuff.

9/10

reviewText:
Definitely a yes to recommend,
I think I got the full version of this like right before they completely stopped vendoring Dreamcast games like in 2003 or 2004. (was gonna get Fur Fighters but that didn't happen) I actually beat this game growing up, maybe spending more than 20 hours playing it.
Looking back now, and currently STRUGGLING to beat Kurts second level I don't see how I did it as a kid. The game does have it's difficult moments but nothing too hard. Literally probably only Kurt's second level (you'll see what part when you get to it)
Because of crap like that I do miss the checkpoints instead of having to save my own my own when I find a safe area.

Haven't played with keyboard yet but the Xbox controller having like an EXTREMELY similar mapping/design to the DC controller made it SUPER easy to adjust... just didn't like having to map things myself (but I'm just lazy)
Sadly partial controller support I believe is a thing so (RB and LB) v (LT and RT) you'd have to go with buttons because If youre jumping and shooting with the triggers cancelling an action is going to happen... so its choosing one or the other. That seeming to be my only controller issue... sensitivity varies from player to player on analog.

The game's story is wacky and comical, something I find enjoyable but probably a bit too wacky and corny even as I was growing up.
A great ending to a great story with none of that twist crap but let me shut my mouth before i start spoiling
4/5

reviewText: The unlikely hero janitor Kurt Hectic makes a return in this action-packed sequel to the 1997 classic MDK. Available for play are also Kurt's employer, Dr. Fluke Hawkins, and his dog Max. Max is a six-legged robotic dog that can quad-wield 4 guns at once. That alone should be enough to persuade you to buy this awesome game. The game has some great humorous moments as well, and did you know Jesper Kyd composed music for this game? Yes - that Jesper Kyd. So needless to say, the music is ♥♥♥♥ing great as well. Get the combo pack of MDK and MDK2 for $14.99 right now, here on Steam.

reviewText: A huge improvement to the original constructed by Bioware. Adds two new playable characters from the original, voice acting, a comic book style plot, between mission custcenes, and a plethora of new powerups. The devs really took advantage of the new character's skill sets to make you wrack your brain at every puzzle while still building on the main character's skills to provide him with a unique trip too.\n\nI recommend getting the double bundle but if you have to chose between them, this is the superior one and can stand on it's own merits as a great game despite being a sequel.

reviewText:
MDK 2, a third person shooter, action-adventure, developed by Bioware, and the sequel to MDK developed by Shiny entertainment. The game follows the adventures of Kurt Hectic, a janitor who uses a chaingun with limitless bullets and a sniper rifle, Max, a six legged dog who smokes cigars and wields four guns, and Dr. Fluke Hawkins who utilises his intelligence to make materials to fix his problems. The game makes you go through 10 levels of killing aliens, giants aliens, and puzzle solving.
Positive/s: The combat system is excellent
Each of the three characters play differently, requiring different strategies to get through each level.
Kickass music.
Entertaining aliens and bosses
A silly but entertaining story.

Overall a very fun and entertaining game.

9 out of 10

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YedUcwPLv8c
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ClVGx9R-fzo

It's one of the Most Zanniest TPS Game I've ever played since the days of Windows 2000/XP!
MDK 2 is a hilarious game from 2000, where we follow janitor Kurt Hectic, robot dog Max and mad scientist Dr. Fluke Hawkins in their struggle to save our planet! While celebrating their very recent victory over invading alien forces, the heroes of MDK 2 discovers that there are still lingering forces around.


MDK2: The World's Spaciest Magazine!!!
Comic Book Narrator: Kurt Hectic never wanted to be a hero.
He was content with his life and wanted to live out his years in quiet dignified anonymity...
Sadly, it was NOT to be.

Kurt was Employed as a Janitor for Dr. Fluke Hawkins; Essentric man of Science.
The Messes were large but the pay was good, so when Hawkins left, Kurt followed...
Little did he know what was to become.

The Doctor had wished for a place away from his detractors;
away from those who thought him mad, with Janitor in tow he left the earth,
vowing to return when his genius was proven.

The Greatest of the Doctor's inventions in Exile was the 6-legged canine; Max.
Max was the perfect assistant
and his apprecation of firepower made him a fine watchdog as well.

All was peaceful until the invasion;
Aliens from a Strange dimension attacked the earth!
Arriving on Energy Streams and landing Great Minecrawlers to destroy everything in their path!
The forces of Earth were helpless before the onslaught!

Dr. Hawkins had to act!
Kurt was outfitted in an Untested Coil Suit & was sent to try and disable the machines.
He was Reluctant but he had no choice; He was the Earth's last hope.

Kurt faught valiantly,
driving to the heart of the Invasion! There he challenged the Alien Leader,
a grotesque creature named; Gunter Glutt! And with Max's aid,
Kurt was Victorious!

As their leader fell,
the Invasion Crumbled & the Aliens Retreated, their tails between their legs.
In their wake, they left the Earth; Better, Despoiled but not Beatten... No, NOT Beaten.

Now with the Aliens routed & Order Restored,
our heroes can return to their normal everyday lives...
Or Can they?! Only time will tell!

reviewText: Dear lord. I REALLY REALLY REALLY wanted to like this game. In the state that it's in, however, I really don't want anyone to do what I did and spend money on this pathetic, broken pile of crap. I loved MDK1 and, while it wasn't as good, MDK2 has only gotten good reviews. Hell, Bioware worked on this one so how terrible could it be? VERY terrible, as the case happens to be. The controls are easy to get used to even if you haven't played before, but the main issue with this game isn't the gameplay, the issue is with the multitude of game-breaking bugs. When I first started playing, everything seemed to be fine and dandy. Then the controls started to stick when I moved around. At first this wasn't an issue, but when I couldn't jump while running towards a cliff or my character just decided to run into an alien's crotch and run in place until I lost half of my health, I began to get rather cross. When I reached the first boss, the game shut my mouse off and I couldn't aim or shoot. ♥♥♥♥♥.

reviewText: This was my first computer game I've ever played and it has aged extremely well.  Don't worry about not playing the first one, you can pick this game up and play it without any problem as the first game was MUCH more lax on the story side of things.  This game is the definition of what it means to be a classic.  As is often the case with Bioware games, the writing is fantastic with comedy being seamlessly interweaved with the high-paced action game that it is.  The level designs do not lack for anything.  They really make you think since every room is like its own puzzle.  I remember when I was young, around 9 or 10, I would be stuck on some rooms for days before my tiny brain put together what I needed to do.  This was an era before I was even aware I could google game walkthroughs, but I loved figuring everything out.  The boss fights are epic, with each boss seeming like a more complex Legend of Zelda boss fight.  Finally, what REALLY sets this game apart for me is the sheer amount of secrets in the game.  This game is from a time when designers could throw in a secret room you accessed by stumbling across an invisible bridge over a never-ending pit or running towards a section of wall that seems slightly off-color from the rest.  They reward you with items, health, or perhaps a joke room with a poorly photoshopped picture of the developers' faces over some cartoon characters.   Either way, these secret rooms do not detract anything from the experience, and they're a real treat to find.  This is a game that does not hold your hand and try to steer you to progress.  No, this game sits and waits for you to progress, expecting you to know what to do or to take as much time as you need to figure it out.

reviewText: I played MDK2 first on the Dreamcast, then the Playstation 2. They were better than the PC version for one tiny simple fact. The graphics weren't as dark. Other than that the graphics were exactly the same between all three platforms and so were the controls and playability. Now I have beaten this PC version, it's just 98% of the time I'm in off-line mode because I don't have internet access where I live so with Steam I'm usually only on it to download the games and I've very apearently played this one for more than 12 minutes. Found out to my surprise writting a review on a game I've beaten from Steam on off-line mode I couldn't post because I've only played it a minute. Well that's a good laugh. On-line now because my system got factory reset and now have to redownload all my steam games. Man this is gonna take weeks. If you ever played MDK 2 on any of the other systems, the PC version is exactly the same except a little too dark which is dulling a beautiful game that is doing alot with it's grapics with surprising low memory. I was surprised how little this game took off my hard drive and yet it looks this good?!? Better yet this is also an awesome game too, well except when I play the Doctor but two out of three isn't bad as you count Maxx and Kirt. Be a sniper or a robotic dog with four arms, each loaded with a gun for massive firepower. The humor on this game is killer too. If you never heard of this game before, do yourself a favor and take a chance on this hidden gem, very likely you wont regret it.
